Who acted as your like your bridge to the
next stage and to the progression of where
you now are in your career.

Like in that early side. Where did they come
from?

Well, one thing I was thinking while you were
saying that is I think like when you're

young, you don't feel like you're the
successful person, right?

You. So all your friends are a version of
you.

Okay. You're just you're trying to break in
and you believe in your friends, like, oh my
God, my friend is the funniest person ever.

And then as you start doing better, I still
feel like one of those people who's trying to

break in. Okay. So I always feel like that's
the space that I'm in.

Okay. Or I want to stay in that space where
everyone I believe in hasn't made it yet.

So when I started, uh, I lived with Sandler
for a while.
Rob Schneider lived across the street.
David Spade lived down the street.

I would drive over the hill to Jim Carrey's
house to help him with stuff, jokes, sketches
for In Living Color.

And I was the one person that was like, I'll
help you write your jokes.
See, everyone wants it to be a star.

So no one wanted to write jokes for anybody
else.

Yeah. I thought, I need to pay my rent, so
if I can get a comedian to give me 50 bucks a
joke to help.
Yeah. That's the best job in the world.
And not many comedians wanted to do that so.
Well, why were you okay with that?

Like what? What is it that you know, early
on?

I mean, the ego is supposed to be present in
the beginning of the career.
See, that's where

my lack of ego worked. Because I think I
always thought, well, I'm not going to be Jim

Carrey, but I can't believe I get to sit
with Jim Carrey and help him.
Wow. I didn't have that.

I wasn't competitive with everyone because I
think in my gut I'm like, you know, we all
loved Bill Murray, we loved Eddie Murphy.

I think the idea in my own head, oh, I'm
going to be like them disappeared very
quickly. But I loved to hang.

I loved that it made people happy to get
jokes.

I love that I could get paid, and I felt
like I love what they're doing so much.
It's so fun to see them succeed.
I was going to

say. I was going to say, when you talk about

days, like the Jim Carrey success on In

And to sit with Jim and Jim's like, I have

and it's kind of like Conan the Barbarian,
and I'm in this little bikini.

It's not just that. It's like there's Jim

He writes most of it because he's a genius,

you're so enthusiastic and you make a

But then he does it and it is a ten.

And that to me was always even more exciting

That was that was the group.

And also there was a feeling like I think

It was more like, we don't know when it's
going to happen.

We don't know how it's going to happen, but

Like, who else at that time were you writing

Well, the first people I wrote for was George
Wallace.

Wow. And George Wallace said, Judd, I have
two types of jokes.
Stupid sh*t.
Things I don't understand.

Then he goes, wait, there's a third
category.
What if I was president?
And so I
sat
down.
And
wrote
jokes like that.
And he's the nicest man in the world.

And the funniest. The one person at the
improv who was always nice to us when we were
nobody, George Wallace.

And then I wrote some jokes for Taylor
Negron.

I got a job writing for Dennis Miller, who
was doing a HBO pregame show to Paul Simon
Live in Central Park.

And so there was a half hour Dennis Miller
hosting, talking about the history of Paul

Simon. And you know, Dennis was unbelievable
at that moment.

This is all is this all word of mouth like,
oh, Judd's a good person.
Like, how were you finding yourself?
Well, I'm in the clubs and I know people.

My manager, Jimmy Miller, Dennis Miller's
brother, uh, he was helping find me work, and

he would, like, tell people like, you should
let Judd write jokes for you.

But everyone needed jokes, so it wasn't,
like, the hardest gigs to get because there

actually weren't many people out there
attempting that.
